definition:
Let $G$ be a finite abelian group, let $L$ be any field containing the
$|G|$-th roots of unity, and let $\hat{G}$ denote the character group of
$G$ with values in $L$. For any character $\chi\in \hat{G}$, we define
$\varepsilon_\chi$, the corresponding *orthogonal idempotent of the
group ring* $L[G]$, by $$\begin{aligned}
\varepsilon_\chi=\frac{1}{|G|}\sum_{g\in G} \chi(g)g^{-1}.\end{aligned}$$

The following equalities hold:

-   $\varepsilon_\chi^2=\varepsilon_\chi$ for all $\chi$

-   $\varepsilon_\chi\varepsilon_\psi=0$ for any $\chi\neq\psi$

-   $\sum_{\chi\in\hat{G}}\varepsilon_\chi=1$

-   $\varepsilon_\chi\cdot g=\chi(g)\varepsilon_\chi$

These orthogonal idempotents are used to decompose modules over $L[G]$:
If $M$ is such a module, then $M=\oplus_\chi (\varepsilon_\chi M)$.
phrase: Orthogonal Idempotents Of The Group Ring
